prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for speaking up about my eldest sisters husband trying to solicit sexual favours from me when I was 13*
*I am now 21

This year I essentially destroyed (my mother’s words) my family by speaking up about my eldest sisters husband trying to solicit sexual favours from me on Christmas Day when I was 13, while everyone else was in their post Christmas feast coma (and didn’t speak up at the time as I was told by him no one would believe me because I was 13 and he was 28 and “who would believe a child over an adult”).

I hated Christmas before this incident because my family always had the tendency to (literally) scream at each other over anything whenever they were forced to occupy the same house, but this incident only made me despise the holidays more.

I spoke up about this in August, because in April I was told that I would be required to drive 8 hours (one way) to spend a week at said eldest sisters house because “that’s what everyone is doing for Christmas” and was told that it didn’t matter what “excuses” I had as my attendance wasn’t “optional”. I was told this by every person in my family, my mother, my father, and my 2 other older sisters (one of which was flying in from London for the week).

In short this year has been a series of severe mental breakdowns for me. I spent months discussing  with my partner at the time what I should do, and the eventual conclusion came that I had to speak up, not just for my sake, but for the sake of all of my sisters children (6 boys and 3 girls between the 3 of them).

Long story short: My eldest sister told my mother and my closest in age sister that myself and both of them were dead to her, as I, in her words, “had to be making everything up to destroy her life when she’s finally happy”, and she would have nothing do to with anyone who believed me.
Eldest sister said that when I apologise and admit to lying about everything that we can “attempt” to be sisters again, to which I told her that I wasn’t lying, and that I didn’t care if I was never considered her sister again, so long as my nieces and nephews were protected in the way that I wasn’t.

No one in my family (bar my mother whom I’m now back living with due to the severity of the decline in my mental health) has spoken to me since August.
My closest sister in age is angry at me for speaking up about it. My mother is beyond upset that I’ve taken some of her grandchildren away from her by speaking up, because my eldest sister said she would never be allowed to see them again, because she ordered my mum to “make this all go away or pick a side”, to which my mother replied that she couldn’t make it go away and that she wouldn’t pick sides.

Am I the asshole? 
This is killing me. 
My mum has always told me that “family will always be there for you and protect you”, and no one in my family was or is really there for me or protected me, but I’m still desperately trying to protect their children, but I feel like I’M the monster for trying to protect them because I’m being blamed for ruining my family?
I don’t know what to do, and I thought I did the right thing, but now I feel like I am the asshole.
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user is asking whether the author of the situation described is in the wrong. The story is about a 21-year-old who is now dealing with family fallout after speaking up about an incident when they were 13, where their eldest sister's husband tried to solicit sexual favors. 

First, I need to consider the moral and legal aspects. The key point here is the age difference. The author was 13 when the incident happened, which is a minor, and the husband was 28. In many places, soliciting sexual favors from a minor is a serious crime, often considered statutory rape or sexual abuse. So from a legal standpoint, the husband's actions are clearly wrong, and the author is a victim.

The author didn't speak up immediately because they were told by the husband that no one would believe a child over an adult. That's a common manipulation tactic in abuse cases. Then, when they did speak up at 21, the family reacted by cutting them off, with the eldest sister cutting ties and threatening to take away the grandchildren from the mother. The mother is now back with the author due to mental health issues.

The user thinks the author is in the wrong, but I need to assess that. The author's intention was to protect themselves and the nieces and nephews. The family's reaction seems to be defending the abuser rather than the victim. This is a red flag. Families sometimes prioritize protecting the abuser's reputation over the victim's well-being, which is harmful and wrong.

The mother's belief that family should always protect each other might have been shaken here. The author's actions were to prevent harm to the children, which is a valid concern. The family's response of cutting off the author seems unjust. In such cases, the victim isn't in the wrong for coming forward, especially when the abuser is in a position of power (being an adult) and the victim was a child.

Mentally, the author has suffered breakdowns and is dealing with the aftermath. The family's reaction exacerbates the trauma. The author is trying to protect the children, which is the right thing to do. Even if the family is upset, the author's actions were justified. The husband's actions were the wrongdoing, not the author's report.

So the answer would be B, the author is not in the wrong. They were a victim and acted to prevent further harm. The family's reaction is misguided and harmful, but that doesn't make the author the asshole.
